sen.j: 国司（こくし）は、古代から中世の日本で、地方行政単位である令制国の行政官として中央から派遣された官吏である。
sen.e: A kokushi was a government officer who, in the ancient times to the medieval period of Japan, was sent to a ryoseikoku (province), an area unit in the nation-governing system in those times, to administer the province, and was given an official status of kami (governor), suke (vice governor), jo (secretary) or saran (clerk) in the shitokan (classifying bureaucrats' statues into four ranks) system (for more information, refer to the local government system in ancient Japan).

A kokushi was a government officer who, during the medieval period of Japan, was sent to a ryoseikoku (province), a unit of area in the nation-governing system in those times, to administer the province, and given official status of kami (governor), suke (vice governor), jo (secretary) or saran (clerk) in the shitokan (classifying bureaucrats' statues into four ranks) system (for more information, refer to the local government system in ancient Japan).
In medieval Japan, a kokushi was a government officer who was sent by the central government to administer a ryoseikoku (an area of regional administration).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。2文に分かれていましたので、一原文一訳文例外処理。

sen.j: 四等官である守 (国司)（かみ）、介 (国司)（すけ）、掾（じょう）、目 (国司)（さかん）等を指す（詳細は古代日本の地方官制も併せて参照のこと）。
sen.e: The four ranks of the kokushi system were known as the shitokan, with the individual ranks being kami (governor), tsuke (vice-governor), jo (secretary) and sakan (clerk) (for more information, refer to 'the local government system in ancient Japan').
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。2文に分かれていましたので、一原文一訳文例外処理。

sen.j: 郡の官吏（郡司）は在地の有力者、いわゆる旧豪族からの任命だった。
sen.e: The officer of a county (called gunji) was appointed by the powerful man in the county, in other words, by a former gozoku (local ruling family).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The officer of a county (called gunji) was appointed by an individual possessing influence within the county, in other words, by a former gozoku (local ruling family).
Gunji (district officials) were appointed by influential people from the region, namely former gozoku (local ruling clan) members.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: そのため、中央からの支配のかなめは国司にあった。
sen.e: Therefore, the kokushi of a province was placed in the core of the central government control of the province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the kokushi of a province was placed at the core of the central government of the province.
For these reasons, the kokushi were pivotal to central government control.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 任期は6年（のちに4年）であった。
sen.e: The period of the assignment was six years (becoming four years later).
The period of the assignment was six years (becoming four years later).
A kokushi's tenure was six (subsequently four) years.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 国司は国衙において政務に当たった。
sen.e: A kokushi did his administration work in the kokuga (provincial government office).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A kokushi carried out his tasks in the kokuga (provincial government office).
A kokushi performed his duties in the kokuga (provincial government office).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 祭祀・行政・司法・軍事のすべてを司り、管内では絶大な権限を持った。
sen.e: Being in charge of all of the festival-related, administrative, judicial and military activities, he held overwhelming authority in the area that he controlled.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Being in charge of all of the festival-related, administrative, judicial and military activities, he held overwhelming authority in the area that he controlled.
He had supreme authority in the area under his jurisdiction and was responsible for all matters pertaining to religious services, administration, the law and the military.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』には、大化の改新時の改新の詔において、国司を置いたことが記録されている。
sen.e: The imperial decree at the Taika Reforms, which was recorded in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), includes the passage that the system of assigning kokushi were introduced then.
The imperial decree at the Taika Reforms, which was recorded in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), includes a passage stating that the system of assigning kokushi were introduced at this time.
The "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) records how the kokushi system was introduced by imperial decree at the time of the Taika Reforms.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。原文の『』に合せて'を"に訂正しました。

sen.j: このとき、全国一律に国司が設置されたとは考えられていなかった。
sen.e: It is not considered that kokushi were assigned throughout the nation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kokushi however, were not considered to have been placed throughout the nation.
At this time there were no plans to distribute kokushi uniformly throughout the country.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: また当初は国宰（くにのみこともち）という呼称されたと言われており、国宰の上には数ヶ国を統括する大宰（おほ みこともち）が設置されたという（「大宰府」の語はその名残だと言われている）。
sen.e: It is also said that kokushi was initially called "kuni no mikoto mochi" as well and that, above "kuni no mikoto mochi," an "oho mikoto mochi (provincial governor-general, 大宰 in the Chinese characters)," who governed several provinces, was placed (the term of 大宰府 (an area name in Kyushu) is said to indicate that such a position existed actually).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is also said that kokushi was initially called "kuni no mikoto mochi" as well and that, above "kuni no mikoto mochi," an "oho mikoto mochi (provincial governor-general, 大宰 in the Chinese characters)," who governed several provinces, were placed (the term of 大宰府 (an area name in Kyushu) is said to indicate that such a position existed actually).

It is said that kokushi were originally known as 'kuni no mikoto mochi' (provincial governors), and above them were the 'oho mikoto mochi' (provincial governor-generals) who were in charge of several provinces (it is said the name 'Dasaifu' (an area in Kyushu) is derived from 'oho mikoto mochi', as it shares the same Chinese characters).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: その後7世紀末までに令制国の制度が確立し、それに伴って国司が全国的に配置されるようになったとされている。
sen.e: After that, the ryoseikoku (province) system was established by the end of seventh century, and kokushi became to be placed throughout the nation accordingly.
After that, the ryoseikoku (province) system was established by the end of the seventh century, and kokushi came to be placed throughout the nation.
From this point on until the end of the 7th century, kokushi were placed throughout the country following the establishment of the ryoseikoku system.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 8世紀初頭には、本格的な法典体系である大宝律令が公布され、中央集権的な律令制が布かれることとなった。
sen.e: In the early eighth century, Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code), a full-fledged law system, was proclaimed and the centralized ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) was established.

In the early eighth century, Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code), a full-fledged law system, was proclaimed and the centralized ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) was established.

In the early 8th century, the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) - a fully-fledged system of law - was issued, and the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code) was established.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 律令制において、国司は非常に重要な位置に置かれた。
sen.e: In the ritsuryo system, kokusi occupied a quite important position.
In the ritsuryo system, kokusi occupied a very important position.
Kokushi occupied a very important position in the Ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 律令制を根幹的に支えた班田収授制は、古代の戸籍制度の作成、田地の班給、租庸調の収取などから構成されていたが、これらはいずれも国司の職務であった。
sen.e: The "handen shuju sei (a system of periodic reallocations of rice land)," which constituted the base of the ritsuryo system, consisted of the creation of the family register system in the ancient times, the hankyu (allotment) of rice fields and land, and the collection of soyocho (tax and corvee), and koskushi was in charge of all of these works.

The "handen shuju sei (a system of periodic reallocations of rice land)," which constituted the base of the ritsuryo system, consisted of the creation of the family registery system in ancient times, the hankyu (allotment) of rice fields and land, and the collection of soyocho (tax and corvee), while koskushi were in charge of all of these.

The Handen Shuju system (a system for periodically reallocating rice land) was the basis of the Ritsuryo system and involved the creation of the ancient family registry system, the allotment of rice fields and the collection of tax/corvee, all tasks carried out by the kokushi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: このように、律令制の理念を日本全国に貫徹することが国司に求められていたのである。
sen.e: In this way, it was asked for kokushi to make the idea of the ritsuryo system penetrated throughout Japan.
In this way, it was asked for kokushi to make the idea of the ritsuryo system penetrated throughout Japan.
In this way, the kokushi were entrusted with spreading the ideas of the Ritsuryo system throughout Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 平安時代になると、朝廷は地方統治の方法を改めた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the imperial court changed the way of controlling the local areas.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Heian period, the imperial court changed its method of controlling local areas.
In the Heian period, the Imperial Court revised the system for governing local areas.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 国司には一定の租税納入を果たすことが主要任務とされ、従前の律令制的な人民統治は求められなくなっていった。
sen.e: The main role of kokushi became to collect and deliver a certain amount of tax, and it became not to be requested for him to govern people in the province as in the former ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Kokushi mainly served to collect and deliver a certain amount of tax, and was not required to govern the people in the province as part of the ritsuryo system.
The main responsibility of the kokushi became the collection of a fixed amount of tax, and they were relieved of the duty of governing, a duty which had been part of the Ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: それは、律令制的な統治方法によらなくとも、一定の租税を徴収することが可能になったからである。
sen.e: This is because it became possible to collect a certain amount of tax without relying on the governing method as in the ritsuryo system.
This is because it became possible to collect a certain amount of tax without relying on the governing method as in the ritsuryo system.
This was because it became possible to collect these taxes without relying on the Ritsuryo system of governance.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 9世紀～10世紀ごろ、田堵と呼ばれる富豪農民が登場し、時を同じくして、国衙（国司の役所）が支配していた公田が、名田という単位に再編された。
sen.e: In around ninth to tenth century, rich farmers called tato (cultivators) appeared and at the same time, the Koden (field administered directly by a ruler), which was controlled by kokuga (kokushi's office), was reorganized into units of myoden (rice field lots in charge of a nominal holder).

Around the ninth to tenth century, rich farmers called tato (cultivators) appeared, while at the same time, the Koden (field administered directly by a ruler), which was controlled by kokuga (kokushi's office), was reorganized into units of myoden (rice field lots in charge of a nominal holder).

A group of rich farmers named the Tato (cultivators) made their appearance around the 9th and 10th centuries, and during the same period, koden (land directly controlled by the kokuga (provincial government office)) was reorganized into units of land known as myoden.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 国司は、田堵に名田を経営させ、名田からの租税納付を請け負わせることで、一定の租税額を確保するようになった（これを負名という）。
sen.e: Kokushi made tato manage myoden and collect tax from the myoden to secure a certain mount of tax (the person who was entrusted with the operation of a myoden was called a fumyo).
Kokushi were ordered to manage myoden and collect tax from the myoden to secure a set amount of taxes (the person who was entrusted with the operation of a myoden was called a fumyo).
The kokushi were able to secure the fixed amount of taxes by entrusting the Tato with the management of and collection of taxes from the myoden (the Tato so entrusted were known as Fumyo).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 律令制下では、人民一人ひとりに租税が課せられていたため、人民の個別支配が必要とされていた。
sen.e: In the ritsuryo system, tax was levied on each individual and therefore, it was necessary to control the people.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the ritsuryo system, tax was levied on each individual and therefore, it was necessary to control the people.
Under the Ritsuryo system, tax was levied on each individual so it was necessary to administer each person individually.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。余分なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: しかし、10世紀ごろになると、上記のように名田、すなわち土地を対象に租税賦課する体制が確立したのである（この体制を名体制（みょうたいせい）という）。
sen.e: However, in around the tenth century, the system to levy tax on myoden, or land in other words, was established as described above (this system is called the myo taisei).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, around the tenth century, the system to levy tax on myoden, or land in other words, was established as described above (this system is called the myo taisei).
However, as described above, around the 10th century a system was established for levying tax on myoden or, in other words, on land (this system was known as the myo taisei).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 一定の租税収入が確保されると、任国へ赴任しない国司が多数現れるようになった（これを遥任という）。
sen.e: When a certain amount of tax became to be secured, many kokushi who did not reside in their assigned provinces appeared (such an assignment style was called a yonin).
When a certain amount of tax was secured, many kokushi who did not reside in their assigned provinces appeared (such an assignment style was called a yonin).
When a fixed amount of tax had been secured, several kokushi appeared from outside the area (these were known as yonin).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: そして現地赴任する国司の中の最高責任者を受領と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: The top of the kokushi who were assigned to and resided in a province became to be called a zuryo.
The top kokushi who were assigned to and resided in a province came to be called a zuryo.
The head of the kokushi who were assigned to and resided in a province became known as the zuryo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 王朝国家体制への転換の中で、受領は一定額の租税の国庫納付を果たしさえすれば、朝廷の制限を受けることなく、それ以上の収入を私的に獲得・蓄積することができるようになった。
sen.e: In the transformation to the system of the dynasty state, zuryo became not to be controlled by the imperial court as long as they delivered a certain amount of tax, and became to be able to privately secure and accumulate the amount of revenue exceeding the tax.

In the transformation to the system of the dynasty state, zuryo came not to be controlled by the imperial court as long as they delivered a certain amount of tax, and became able to privately secure and accumulate revenues which xceeded the set tax amount.

With the switch to this new system, known as the Ocho Kokka system, as long as the zuryo delivered a set amount of tax to the treasury, they were free from control by the imperial court and were able to privately secure/accumulate any revenues that exceeded the set amount.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 当時、国司に任命されたのは主に中級貴族だったが、彼らは私的に蓄積した富を摂関家などの有力貴族へ貢納することで、生き残りを図った。
sen.e: At that time, middle class royals were mostly assigned to kokushi, and for survival, they donated their privately accumulated resources to powerful royals, such as the sekkan-ke (lines of regents and advisers).

At that time, middle class royals were mostly assigned to kokushi, and for survival, they donated their privately accumulated resources to powerful royals, such as the sekkan-ke (lines of regents and advisers).
At that time, it was mainly middle-ranking royalty who were assigned to be kokushi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: また、国司に任命されることは富の蓄積へ直結したため、中級貴族は競って国司への任命を望み、また重任を望んだ。
sen.e: Furthermore, because being assigned to kokushi was connected directly to accumulate resources, middle class royals competed to be assigned to kokushi and desired to be assigned to the position more than once.

Furthermore, because being assigned to kokushi was connected directly to accumulate resources, middle class royals competed to be assigned to kokushi and desired to be assigned to the position more than once.
Furthermore, a kokushi assignment was directly connected to the accumulation of wealth, so middle-ranking royalty fought for the appointments and also sought to be reappointed.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 『枕草子』には国司任命（除目という）の日の悲喜を描いている。
sen.e: "Makura no Soshi (The Pillow Book)" includes a description of the day when a person was assigned to kokushi (the assigning ceremony is called a jimoku).
"Makura no Soshi (The Pillow Book)" includes a description of the day when a person was assigned to kokushi (the assigning ceremony is called a jimoku).
"Makura no Soshi "(The Pillow Book) includes a description of the day when a person was assigned to kokushi (the assigning ceremony is called a jimoku).
sen.cmt: " の位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 平安中期以降、知行国という制度ができた。
sen.e: In the middle or later of the Heian period, the chigyo-koku system (see the next sentence) was established.
In the middle and later periods of the Heian period, the chigyo-koku system (see the next sentence) was established.
In the middle and later periods of the Heian period, the chigyo-koku system (see the next sentence) was established.

sen.j: これは皇族や大貴族に一国を指定して国司推薦権を与えるもので、大貴族は親族や家来を国司に任命させて当国から莫大な収益を得た。
sen.e: In this system, the right to recommend the kokushi of a province was given to a member of the imperial family or a dominant royal, and the dominant royal, who was given the right, appointed his family member or vassal to the kokushi, obtaining a vast amount of income from the province.

In this system, the right to recommend the kokushi of a province was given to a member of the imperial family or a dominant royal, and the dominant royal, who was given the right, appointed his family member or vassal to the kokushi, obtaining a vast amount of income from the province.

In this system, the right to recommend the kokushi of a province was given to a member of the imperial family or a dominant royal, and the dominant royal, who was given the right, appointed his family member or vassal to the kokushi, obtaining a vast amount of income from the province.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代にも国司は存続した。
sen.e: Kokushi existed in the Kamakura period as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kokushi existed in the Kamakura period as well.
Kokushi existed in the Kamakura period as well.

sen.j: しかし、幕府によって各地に配置された地頭が積極的に荘園、そして国司が管理していた国衙領へ侵出していった。
sen.e: However, the jito (the manager and lord of a manor) placed in various areas by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) made inroads into manors and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) actively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the jito (the manager and lord of a manor) placed in various areas by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) made active inroads into manors and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).

However, the bakufu (military government) dispatched jito (estate stewards) to several areas, and these jito became actively involved in the shoen (manors) and the kokugaryo (public lands) administered by the kokushi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: 当然、これに国司は抵抗した。
sen.e: Naturally, Kokushi resisted such a situation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Naturally, the Kokushi resisted this situation.
Naturally, the kokushi resisted this situation.

sen.j: しかしながら、地頭は国衙領へ侵出することで、徐々に国司の支配権を奪っていった。
sen.e: However, jito made inroads into Kokugaryo, depriving kokushi of their right of controlling the provinces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, jito made inroads into Kokugaryo, depriving kokushi of their right to control the provinces.
However, jito made inroads into Kokugaryo, depriving kokushi of their right to control the provinces.

sen.j: 室町時代になると、守護に大幅な権限、例えば半済給付権、使節遵行権などが付与された。
sen.e: Entering into the Muromachi period, substantial rights, for examples, the hanzei-kyufu right (the right that a half of tax can be gained) and the sisetsu-jungyo right (the right to send personnel and execute an instruction of the bakufu), were given to shugo (provincial constable).

Entering into the Muromachi period, substantial rights, for examples, the hanzei-kyufu right (the right that a half of tax can be gained) and the sisetsu-jungyo right (the right to send personnel and execute an instruction of the bakufu), were given to shugo (provincial constable).

Shugo (provincial constables) were granted substantial rights entering the Muromachi period, for example the hanzei kyufu (the right to collect half the tax from an area) and the shisetsu jungyo (the right to settle land disputes on behalf of the bakufu).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: これらの権限は、国司が管理する国衙領においても強力な効力を発揮し、その結果、国司の権限が大幅に守護へ移ることとなった。
sen.e: These rights exhibited strong effects even in the Kokugaryo where kokushi had managed, resulting in that many rights of kokushi were transferred to Shugo.
These rights exhibited strong effects even in the Kokugaryo where kokushi had managed, resulting in that many rights of kokushi were transferred to Shugo.
These rights also exerted a strong effect in the kokugaryo lands administered by the kokushi, resulting in a substantial transferal of kokushi rights to the shugo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: こうして国司は名目だけの官職となり、実体的な支配は守護（守護大名という）が執行するようになった。
sen.e: In this way, Kokushi became a nominal government officer position, and real control was moved to shugo (called shugo daimyo (a daimyo: a territorial lord)).
In this way, Kokushi became a nominal government officer position, and real control was moved to shugo (called shugo daimyo (a daimyo: a territorial lord)).
In this way, the kokushi became government officers in name only and real power shifted to the shugo (these people were known as shugo daimyo (shugo lords)).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき訂正しました。

sen.j: ここに至り、国司は単なる名誉職となった。
sen.e: Then kokushi became only a honorary post.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The kokushi evolved to become only an honorary post.
The kokushi evolved to become only an honorary post.

sen.j: 従って、被官される人物の実効支配地に関係なく任命された。
sen.e: Therefore, it became not a problem whether the person appointed to the koskushi of a province controlled it actually or not.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the role of kokushi was appointed to someone irregardless of whether they were in control of the province or not.
Therefore, the role of kokushi was appointed to someone irregardless of whether they were in control of the province or not.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)の武将などでは国司を自称、あるいは僭称する者も多かった。
sen.e: In the sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan, many busho (Japanese military commanders) called themselves kokushi or pretended to be kokushi.
In the sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan, many busho (Japanese military commanders) called themselves kokushi or pretended to be kokushi.
